courses.title: Python for Beginners
courses.description: A 30-day beginner-friendly Python course that teaches coding fundamentals through hands-on practice.

days.title: Introduction to Python
days.content: Welcome to Python! Python is a popular programming language known for its simple, readable syntax. It's used for web development, data analysis, artificial intelligence, and more. Today, we'll write our first Python program. In Python, we use the print() function to display text on the screen. Anything inside the parentheses will be printed. For example, print('Hello') would display Hello.
days.interactive_task: Write a Python program that prints your name.

quiz.question: Who created Python?
What function is used to display text in Python?
Which of these is a correct Python print statement?
Python is known for being:
What symbol is used for comments in Python?

days.title: Variables and Data Types
days.content: Variables are like containers that store data. In Python, you create a variable by giving it a name and assigning a value with the = sign. Python has different data types: strings (text), integers (whole numbers), floats (decimal numbers), and booleans (True/False). For example: name = 'Alice' creates a string variable, age = 25 creates an integer variable.
days.interactive_task: Create two variables: one for your favorite food (string) and one for your age (integer), then print them.

quiz.question: Which symbol is used to assign values to variables in Python?
What data type would 3.14 be classified as?
Which of these is a valid variable name in Python?
What data type represents True or False values?
Which of these creates a string variable?

days.title: Basic Operators
days.content: Operators are symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Python has arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /, %) for math operations, and comparison operators (==, !=, >, <, >=, <=) for comparing values. For example: 5 + 3 equals 8, and 10 > 5 evaluates to True.
days.interactive_task: Create two number variables and use arithmetic operators to calculate their sum, difference, and product.

quiz.question: What does the % operator do in Python?
Which operator checks if two values are equal?
What is the result of 10 / 3 in Python?
Which operator would you use to check if a number is greater than 5?
What does the != operator mean?

days.title: String Operations
days.content: Strings are sequences of characters. You can perform various operations on strings like concatenation (joining strings with +), repetition (with *), and accessing individual characters. Python also has many built-in string methods like .upper(), .lower(), .strip() to modify strings. For example: 'hello' + 'world' becomes 'helloworld', and 'hello'.upper() becomes 'HELLO'.
days.interactive_task: Create two string variables and concatenate them. Then convert the result to uppercase.

quiz.question: How do you concatenate two strings in Python?
What does 'hello'.upper() return?
Which method removes whitespace from the beginning and end of a string?
What is the result of 'hi' * 3?
How do you access the first character of a string variable 'name'?

days.title: Lists and Basic List Operations
days.content: Lists are collections of items in Python. You create a list by placing items inside square brackets [], separated by commas. Lists can contain different data types. You can access list items by their index (position), with the first item at index 0. For example: fruits = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry'] creates a list, and fruits[0] returns 'apple'.
days.interactive_task: Create a list of your three favorite hobbies and print the second hobby in the list.

quiz.question: How do you create an empty list in Python?
What index is the first item in a list?
Which method adds an item to the end of a list?
How do you get the number of items in a list?
What does fruits[1] return if fruits = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']?

days.title: If Statements
days.content: If statements allow your program to make decisions. They execute code only when a condition is True. The basic structure is: if condition: followed by indented code. You can also add elif (else if) for additional conditions, and else for when all conditions are False. For example: if age >= 18: print('Adult') else: print('Minor')
days.interactive_task: Write a program that checks if a number is positive, negative, or zero and prints the result.

quiz.question: What keyword starts a conditional statement in Python?
How do you add an alternative condition to an if statement?
What is used to group code blocks in Python?
Which operator checks if a number is greater than or equal to 10?
What will be printed if x = 5 and we run: if x > 3: print('Big') else: print('Small')?

days.title: For Loops
days.content: For loops let you repeat code a specific number of times or iterate over items in a collection. The basic syntax is: for item in collection: followed by indented code. For example: for fruit in fruits: print(fruit) would print each fruit in the fruits list. You can also use range() to generate a sequence of numbers to loop through.
days.interactive_task: Use a for loop to print each number from 1 to 5.

quiz.question: What keyword is used to create a for loop in Python?
What does range(5) generate?
How do you iterate through each character in a string?
What will this code print: for i in range(3): print(i)
Which function is commonly used with for loops to generate number sequences?

days.title: While Loops
days.content: While loops repeat code as long as a condition remains True. The syntax is: while condition: followed by indented code. Unlike for loops that run a specific number of times, while loops continue until the condition becomes False. Be careful to avoid infinite loops by ensuring the condition eventually becomes False.
days.interactive_task: Use a while loop to print numbers from 1 to 3.

quiz.question: What keyword is used to create a while loop?
When does a while loop stop executing?
options: When it reaches a break statement

quiz.question: What is an infinite loop?
options: A loop that only runs at night

quiz.question: How can you manually exit a loop?
What will this code do: while True: print('Hello')

days.title: Functions Basics
days.content: Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. You define a function using the def keyword, followed by the function name and parentheses. Functions can take parameters (inputs) and return values. For example: def greet(name): return 'Hello ' + name creates a function that takes a name and returns a greeting.
days.interactive_task: Create a function that takes two numbers as parameters and returns their sum.

quiz.question: What keyword is used to define a function in Python?
What are the inputs to a function called?
What keyword is used to return a value from a function?
How do you call a function named 'calculate'?
What happens if a function doesn't have a return statement?

days.title: Dictionaries
days.content: Dictionaries store data as key-value pairs. You create a dictionary with curly braces {} and separate keys and values with colons. Each key must be unique, and you can access values using their keys. For example: person = {'name': 'Alice', 'age': 30} creates a dictionary, and person['name'] returns 'Alice'.
days.interactive_task: Create a dictionary to store information about yourself (name, age, city) and print your name from the dictionary.

quiz.question: How do you create an empty dictionary?
How do you access the value associated with key 'age' in a dictionary?
What happens if you try to access a key that doesn't exist in a dictionary?
Which method adds a new key-value pair to a dictionary?
How do you get all the keys from a dictionary?

days.title: Tuples and Sets
days.content: Tuples are like lists but immutable (cannot be changed after creation). You create tuples with parentheses (). Sets are unordered collections of unique items. You create sets with curly braces {}. Sets automatically remove duplicates. For example: coordinates = (10, 20) creates a tuple, and colors = {'red', 'blue', 'green'} creates a set.
days.interactive_task: Create a tuple with three of your favorite numbers and a set with three favorite colors.

quiz.question: How do you create a tuple with one item?
What is the main difference between tuples and lists?
What happens if you try to add duplicate items to a set?
Which data structure would you use for coordinates that shouldn't change?
How do you add an item to a set?

days.title: List Comprehensions
days.content: List comprehensions provide a concise way to create lists. They consist of brackets containing an expression followed by a for clause, and optionally more for or if clauses. For example: squares = [x**2 for x in range(5)] creates [0, 1, 4, 9, 16]. They're more readable and often faster than traditional loops.
days.interactive_task: Use a list comprehension to create a list of even numbers from 0 to 10.

quiz.question: What is the basic structure of a list comprehension?
How would you add a condition to only include even numbers?
options: [x for x in range(10) if x % 2 == 0]
[x for x in range(10) where x % 2 == 0]
[x for x in range(10) when x % 2 == 0]
[x for x in range(10) condition x % 2 == 0]
quiz.answer: [x for x in range(10) if x % 2 == 0]

quiz.question: What does [x.upper() for x in ['a', 'b', 'c']] create?
Which is more readable for simple transformations?
What does [x for x in 'hello'] create?

days.title: Error Handling with Try-Except
days.content: Errors are inevitable in programming, but we can handle them gracefully using try-except blocks. Code that might cause an error goes in the try block, and error handling code goes in the except block. For example: try: number = int('abc') except ValueError: print('That is not a valid number!')
days.interactive_task: Write a program that tries to convert user input to a number, and handles the ValueError if the input is not a number.

quiz.question: What keyword starts the block where you put code that might cause an error?
What keyword handles specific types of errors?
What happens if an error occurs in the try block?
Which exception occurs when converting a non-numeric string to int?
What can you use to get information about the error?

days.title: File Handling - Reading Files
days.content: Python can read from and write to files on your computer. To read a file, you use the open() function with the file path and mode 'r' for reading. Always close files after using them, or use the with statement which automatically closes the file. For example: with open('file.txt', 'r') as file: content = file.read()
days.interactive_task: Create a text file with some content, then write a Python program to read and print its contents.

quiz.question: What function is used to open a file?
What mode is used for reading files?
Why is the 'with' statement recommended for file handling?
Which method reads the entire file content as a string?
What happens if you try to open a file that doesn't exist in read mode?

days.title: File Handling - Writing Files
days.content: To write to files, use mode 'w' (write) or 'a' (append). 'w' overwrites the entire file, while 'a' adds to the end of the file. Use the write() method to add content. Remember that write() doesn't automatically add newlines - you need to add \n if you want them. For example: with open('file.txt', 'w') as file: file.write('Hello World!')
days.interactive_task: Write a program that asks for user's name and writes it to a file.

quiz.question: What mode is used for writing to a file (overwriting existing content)?
What mode is used for appending to a file?
What method is used to write content to a file?
What happens to existing content when you open a file in 'w' mode?
How do you write multiple lines to a file?

days.title: Introduction to Classes and Objects
days.content: Classes are blueprints for creating objects. Objects have attributes (data) and methods (functions). You define a class with the class keyword. The __init__ method is a special method that runs when an object is created. For example: class Dog: def __init__(self, name): self.name = name creates a Dog class with a name attribute.
days.interactive_task: Create a simple Person class with name and age attributes, then create an object of that class.

quiz.question: What keyword is used to define a class?
What is the special method called that runs when an object is created?
What does 'self' refer to in a class method?
How do you create an object from a class?
What are the functions inside a class called?

days.title: Class Methods and Attributes
days.content: Classes can have instance attributes (unique to each object) and class attributes (shared by all objects). Methods can be instance methods (work with object data), class methods (work with the class), or static methods (don't need object or class data). Instance methods take self as first parameter, class methods take cls.
days.interactive_task: Add a method to your Person class that introduces the person (e.g., 'Hello, my name is...').

quiz.question: What is the first parameter of an instance method?
What decorator is used for class methods?
What is the first parameter of a class method?
Which type of attribute is shared by all objects of a class?
What decorator is used for static methods?

days.title: Inheritance
days.content: Inheritance allows a class to inherit attributes and methods from another class. The class being inherited from is called the parent or base class, and the class that inherits is called the child or derived class. This promotes code reuse. For example: class Student(Person): would create a Student class that inherits from Person.
days.interactive_task: Create a Student class that inherits from your Person class and adds a grade attribute.

quiz.question: How do you specify that a class inherits from another class?
What is the parent class also called?
How can a child class access parent class methods?
What is method overriding?
options: Changing a parent method in the child class
quiz.answer: Changing a parent method in the child class

quiz.question: What does isinstance() check?
options: If an object is a class
If an object is an instance of a class
quiz.answer: If an object is an instance of a class

days.title: Modules and Importing
days.content: Modules are Python files that contain code you can use in other programs. You can import entire modules or specific functions/classes from modules. Python has many built-in modules like math, random, and datetime. For example: import math lets you use math.sqrt(4), and from math import sqrt lets you use sqrt(4) directly.
days.interactive_task: Import the math module and use it to calculate the square root of 16.

quiz.question: What keyword is used to import a module?
How do you import only the sqrt function from math?
What module would you use for random numbers?
How do you give a module an alias when importing?
What does from module import * do?

days.title: Working with Dates and Times
days.content: The datetime module provides classes for working with dates and times. datetime.date for dates, datetime.time for times, and datetime.datetime for both. You can create date objects, get current date/time, and perform calculations with dates. For example: from datetime import datetime; today = datetime.now()
days.interactive_task: Write a program that prints the current date and time.

quiz.question: Which module is used for working with dates and times?
How do you get the current date and time?
What does datetime.date.today() return?
How do you create a specific date?
What method formats a date as a string?

days.title: Working with JSON Data
days.content: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a popular data format. Python's json module can convert between JSON strings and Python objects. json.loads() converts JSON string to Python object, json.dumps() converts Python object to JSON string. This is useful for working with APIs and configuration files.
days.interactive_task: Create a Python dictionary and convert it to a JSON string, then convert it back to a dictionary.

quiz.question: Which module is used for working with JSON in Python?
What does json.loads() do?
options: Converts JSON string to Python object
Converts Python object to JSON string
quiz.answer: Converts JSON string to Python object

quiz.question: What does json.dumps() do?
options: Converts JSON string to Python object
Converts Python object to JSON string
quiz.answer: Converts Python object to JSON string

quiz.question: Which Python data type is most similar to a JSON object?
How do you read JSON from a file?

days.title: Virtual Environments
days.content: Virtual environments keep dependencies required by different projects separate. They allow you to work on multiple projects with different package versions without conflicts. Use python -m venv myenv to create a virtual environment, then activate it. Install packages with pip while the environment is active.
days.interactive_task: Create a virtual environment and install the requests library using pip.

quiz.question: What is the main purpose of virtual environments?
What command creates a virtual environment?
How do you activate a virtual environment on Windows?
What tool is used to install packages in Python?
Where are packages installed when a virtual environment is active?

days.title: Basic Algorithms - Linear Search
days.content: Algorithms are step-by-step procedures for solving problems. Linear search is a simple algorithm that checks each element in a list until it finds the target. It's easy to implement but can be slow for large lists. For example: for item in list: if item == target: return True
days.interactive_task: Implement a linear search function that takes a list and a target value, and returns True if the target is in the list.

quiz.question: What is the time complexity of linear search?
How many comparisons does linear search make in the worst case?
When is linear search a good choice?
options: For small lists or unsorted data
quiz.answer: For small lists or unsorted data

quiz.question: What does linear search return if the target is not found?
Can linear search work on unsorted lists?

days.title: Basic Algorithms - Bubble Sort
days.content: Bubble sort is a simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly steps through the list, compares adjacent elements and swaps them if they are in the wrong order. The pass through the list is repeated until the list is sorted. It's not efficient for large lists but is easy to understand.
days.interactive_task: Implement bubble sort to sort a list of numbers in ascending order.

quiz.question: What is the time complexity of bubble sort?
How does bubble sort work?
When is bubble sort a good choice?
options: When you need the fastest sort
For educational purposes or small lists
quiz.answer: For educational purposes or small lists

quiz.question: What is the best-case time complexity of bubble sort?
How many passes does bubble sort need in the worst case?

days.title: Working with APIs - Requests
days.content: APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) allow programs to communicate. The requests library is used to make HTTP requests in Python. You can GET data from APIs, POST data to them, and more. For example: response = requests.get('https://api.example.com/data') gets data from an API.
days.interactive_task: Use the requests library to get data from a public API (like jsonplaceholder.typicode.com) and print the response.

quiz.question: What library is commonly used for HTTP requests in Python?
What method is used to get data from an API?
What does response.json() do?
options: Parses JSON response to Python object
quiz.answer: Parses JSON response to Python object

quiz.question: What status code indicates success?
How do you check if a request was successful?

days.title: List Manipulation Techniques
days.content: Python offers many ways to manipulate lists beyond basic operations. You can slice lists with [start:end:step], use methods like .sort(), .reverse(), .count(), .index(), and combine lists with + or .extend(). List slicing creates a new list with specified elements.
days.interactive_task: Create a list of numbers, then use slicing to get every second element and reverse the list.

quiz.question: What does my_list[1:4] return?
How do you reverse a list in place?
What does my_list[-1] return?
How do you find the index of an element in a list?
What does my_list[::2] do?

days.title: Dictionary Methods and Operations
days.content: Dictionaries have many useful methods beyond basic access. .get() safely retrieves values (returns None if key doesn't exist), .items() returns key-value pairs, .update() merges dictionaries, and dictionary comprehensions create dictionaries concisely. These make dictionary manipulation powerful and efficient.
days.interactive_task: Use dictionary comprehension to create a dictionary where keys are numbers 1-5 and values are their squares.

quiz.question: What does dict.get(key) return if the key doesn't exist?
How do you get all key-value pairs as tuples?
What is the syntax for dictionary comprehension?
How do you remove a key from a dictionary?
What does dict.update(other_dict) do?

days.title: Working with External Libraries
days.content: Python's strength comes from its vast ecosystem of external libraries. You can install libraries using pip, import them in your code, and leverage their functionality. Popular libraries include requests for HTTP, pandas for data analysis, matplotlib for plotting, and numpy for numerical computing.
days.interactive_task: Install and use the matplotlib library to create a simple line plot.

quiz.question: How do you install a library using pip?
Which library is used for data analysis with DataFrames?
Which library is used for creating plots and charts?
What does import pandas as pd do?
Where can you find Python packages to install?

days.title: Debugging Techniques
days.content: Debugging is finding and fixing errors in code. Basic techniques include using print statements to track variable values, reading error messages carefully, and using Python's built-in debugger (pdb). The pdb module lets you set breakpoints, step through code, and inspect variables.
days.interactive_task: Write a function with a bug and use print statements to debug it.

quiz.question: What is the simplest debugging technique?
How do you import the Python debugger?
How do you set a breakpoint in code?
What does 'n' do in pdb?
What should you do first when you encounter an error?

days.title: Final Project - Building a Simple Application
days.content: Let's combine everything we've learned to build a simple contact management system. We'll create classes for contacts, use lists to store them, implement functions to add, view, and search contacts, and save/load data from a file. This project will reinforce all the Python concepts covered in this course.
days.interactive_task: Build a contact management system that can add contacts, view all contacts, search for contacts by name, and save/load contacts from a file.

quiz.question: What Python concept is most useful for storing contact information?
Which file handling mode should you use to save contacts?
What data structure is best for searching contacts by name?
Which algorithm could you use to search for contacts?
What should you use to handle errors when loading contacts?

courses.title: JavaScript for Beginners
courses.description: A 25-day beginner-friendly JavaScript course that teaches web programming fundamentals through hands-on practice.

days.title: Introduction to JavaScript
days.content: JavaScript is a programming language that makes web pages interactive. It runs in web browsers and can manipulate HTML and CSS. Unlike Python, JavaScript uses semicolons at the end of statements and curly braces {} for code blocks. You can write JavaScript directly in HTML files or in separate .js files.
days.interactive_task: Write JavaScript code that displays an alert with the message 'Hello World!'

quiz.question: Where does JavaScript primarily run?
What is the correct way to display a message in an alert box?
Which symbol is used for comments in JavaScript?
What file extension do JavaScript files use?
JavaScript is mainly used for:

days.title: Variables and Data Types
days.content: JavaScript variables can be declared with var, let, or const. let and const are modern and preferred. JavaScript has dynamic typing - variables can hold different data types. Basic data types include: String (text), Number (integers and decimals), Boolean (true/false), undefined, and null.
days.interactive_task: Declare variables for your name (string), age (number), and whether you like programming (boolean), then log them to the console.

quiz.question: Which keyword creates a variable that cannot be reassigned?
What is the result of typeof 42?
Which of these is a valid variable name?
What does const do?
What is the value of a declared but unassigned variable?

days.title: Operators and Expressions
days.content: JavaScript has arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /, %), comparison operators (==, ===, !=, !==, >, <), and logical operators (&&, ||, !). The === operator checks both value and type, while == only checks value (and performs type conversion). For example: 5 == '5' is true, but 5 === '5' is false.
days.interactive_task: Create two variables with numbers and use operators to calculate their sum, check if they're equal, and check if both are greater than 0.

quiz.question: What does the % operator do?
Which operator checks both value and type?
What is the result of 10 + '5' in JavaScript?
Which logical operator means 'AND'?
What does the ! operator do?

days.title: Conditional Statements
days.content: JavaScript uses if, else if, and else for conditional logic. The syntax uses parentheses for the condition and curly braces for the code blocks. You can also use the ternary operator for simple conditions: condition ? valueIfTrue : valueIfFalse.
days.interactive_task: Write a program that checks if a number is positive, negative, or zero and logs the result.

quiz.question: What keyword starts a conditional statement?
How do you write 'else if' in JavaScript?
What is the syntax of the ternary operator?
options: if condition then value else value

quiz.question: Which symbol is used for code blocks in JavaScript?
What will be logged if x = 0: if (x) { console.log('Truthy') } else { console.log('Falsy') }?

days.title: Functions
days.content: Functions are reusable blocks of code. In JavaScript, you can define functions with the function keyword or with arrow functions. Functions can take parameters and return values. Function declarations are hoisted (can be called before they're defined), but function expressions are not.
days.interactive_task: Create a function that takes two numbers as parameters and returns their sum.

quiz.question: What keyword is used to define a function?
What is the arrow function syntax?
How do you return a value from a function?
What is hoisting?
How do you call a function named greet?

days.title: Arrays
days.content: Arrays are ordered collections of items. You create arrays with square brackets [] and access elements by their index (starting at 0). JavaScript arrays can hold mixed data types and have many useful methods like .push(), .pop(), .shift(), .unshift(), and .length property.
days.interactive_task: Create an array of your three favorite foods and log the second item.

quiz.question: How do you create an empty array?
What index is the first item in an array?
Which method adds an item to the end of an array?
How do you get the number of items in an array?
What does .pop() do?

days.title: Objects
days.content: Objects store data as key-value pairs. You create objects with curly braces {} and access properties with dot notation or bracket notation. Objects can contain functions as methods. For example: let person = {name: 'Alice', age: 30, greet: function() { console.log('Hello!'); }}
days.interactive_task: Create an object representing yourself with name, age, and a method that introduces you.

quiz.question: How do you create an empty object?
How do you access the name property of a person object?
What are functions inside objects called?
How do you add a new property to an object?
What keyword refers to the current object in a method?

days.title: Loops - For and While
days.content: Loops repeat code. JavaScript has for loops (for a specific number of iterations), while loops (while a condition is true), and do-while loops (execute at least once). For loops are commonly used with arrays. The syntax is: for (let i = 0; i < 5; i++) { console.log(i); }
days.interactive_task: Use a for loop to log numbers from 1 to 5.

quiz.question: What are the three parts of a for loop?
When does a while loop stop?
What does i++ mean?
How do you exit a loop early?
What loop always executes at least once?

days.title: Array Methods
days.content: JavaScript arrays have powerful methods for manipulation. .forEach() executes a function for each item, .map() creates a new array by transforming each item, .filter() creates a new array with items that pass a test, and .find() returns the first item that passes a test. These are often used with arrow functions.
days.interactive_task: Use .map() to create a new array where each number in [1,2,3] is doubled.

quiz.question: What does .map() do?
Which method returns only elements that pass a test?
What does .forEach() return?
Which method finds the first element that matches a condition?
How do you use .map() with an arrow function?

days.title: DOM Manipulation - Selecting Elements
days.content: The DOM (Document Object Model) represents the HTML document as objects that JavaScript can manipulate. You can select elements using document.getElementById(), document.querySelector(), and document.querySelectorAll(). Once selected, you can change their content, styles, and attributes.
days.interactive_task: Select an HTML element by its ID and change its text content.

quiz.question: What does DOM stand for?
How do you select an element by its ID?
What does document.querySelector() return?
How do you change the text of an element?
What does document.querySelectorAll() return?

days.title: DOM Manipulation - Modifying Elements
days.content: After selecting DOM elements, you can modify them in many ways: change content with .textContent or .innerHTML, modify styles with .style.property, change attributes with .setAttribute(), and add/remove classes with .classList.add()/.classList.remove(). You can also create new elements with document.createElement().
days.interactive_task: Change the background color of an element and add a CSS class to it.

quiz.question: How do you change an element's background color?
What's the difference between textContent and innerHTML?
How do you add a CSS class to an element?
How do you create a new div element?
How do you add a created element to the page?

days.title: Events
days.content: Events are actions that happen in the browser, like clicks, key presses, or page loads. You can listen for events using .addEventListener() and run code when they occur. The event object passed to the handler contains information about the event. Common events include 'click', 'keydown', 'mouseover', and 'submit'.
days.interactive_task: Add a click event listener to a button that shows an alert when clicked.

quiz.question: How do you add an event listener?
What is the first parameter of addEventListener?
What event occurs when a button is clicked?
How do you prevent a form from submitting?
What property tells which key was pressed?

days.title: String Methods
days.content: JavaScript strings have many useful methods. .toUpperCase() and .toLowerCase() change case, .trim() removes whitespace, .includes() checks if a string contains another string, .slice() extracts parts of a string, and .split() divides a string into an array. Strings are immutable - these methods return new strings.
days.interactive_task: Take a string with extra spaces, trim it, and convert it to uppercase.

quiz.question: What does 'hello'.toUpperCase() return?
Which method removes spaces from both ends?
What does 'hello'.includes('ell') return?
What does 'hello'.slice(1, 4) return?
What does 'a,b,c'.split(',') return?

days.title: Number and Math Methods
days.content: JavaScript has a Math object with mathematical functions and constants. Math.round() rounds to nearest integer, Math.floor() rounds down, Math.ceil() rounds up, Math.random() returns a random number between 0-1, and Math.max()/Math.min() find largest/smallest numbers. Numbers also have methods like .toFixed() for formatting.
days.interactive_task: Generate a random number between 1 and 10 and round it to the nearest integer.

quiz.question: How do you generate a random number between 0 and 1?
What does Math.floor(3.7) return?
How do you round 2.5 to the nearest integer?
What does (3.14159).toFixed(2) return?
How do you find the larger of two numbers?

days.title: Date and Time
days.content: The Date object handles dates and times in JavaScript. Create dates with new Date(), which gives the current date/time, or with specific parameters. You can get components with methods like .getFullYear(), .getMonth(), .getDate(), .getHours(), etc. Dates can be formatted as strings with .toString() or .toLocaleString().
days.interactive_task: Create a Date object for your birthday and log it in a readable format.

quiz.question: How do you create a Date object with the current date/time?
What does .getMonth() return for January?
How do you get the full year (4 digits)?
What does .toLocaleString() do?
How do you create a date for a specific year, month, day?

days.title: Error Handling with Try-Catch
days.content: JavaScript handles errors with try-catch blocks. Code that might throw an error goes in the try block, and error handling code goes in the catch block. You can also use a finally block that runs regardless of whether an error occurred. This prevents your program from crashing when errors happen.
days.interactive_task: Write code that tries to parse JSON and catches any errors that occur.

quiz.question: What keyword starts the error-prone code block?
What keyword handles the error?
What block always executes?
How do you throw a custom error?
What happens if an error occurs in the try block?

days.title: Local Storage
days.content: The localStorage API allows you to store data in the browser that persists between sessions. Data is stored as key-value pairs (both must be strings). Use localStorage.setItem(key, value) to save, localStorage.getItem(key) to retrieve, and localStorage.removeItem(key) to delete. Data remains until cleared by the user or your code.
days.interactive_task: Save your name to localStorage, then retrieve and display it.

quiz.question: How do you save data to localStorage?
What data types can localStorage store?
How do you retrieve data from localStorage?
How do you remove an item from localStorage?
How long does localStorage data persist?

days.title: JSON in JavaScript
days.content: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is closely related to JavaScript objects. Use JSON.stringify() to convert JavaScript objects to JSON strings, and JSON.parse() to convert JSON strings back to JavaScript objects. This is useful for storing objects in localStorage or sending data to servers.
days.interactive_task: Create a JavaScript object, convert it to JSON string, then parse it back to an object.

quiz.question: How do you convert an object to a JSON string?
How do you parse a JSON string to an object?
What happens if you try to parse invalid JSON?
Can JSON represent functions?
What's the main use of JSON in web development?

days.title: Fetch API - Getting Data
days.content: The Fetch API is used to make HTTP requests to servers. fetch(url) returns a Promise that resolves to the Response object. You need to call .json() on the response to get the actual data. Fetch uses modern Promise syntax and is cleaner than older XMLHttpRequest.
days.interactive_task: Use fetch to get data from a public API and log the response.

quiz.question: What does fetch() return?
How do you extract JSON from a fetch response?
What is a Promise?
How do you handle errors in fetch?
What HTTP method does fetch use by default?

days.title: Async/Await
days.content: Async/await is syntactic sugar for working with Promises. Mark a function as async to use await inside it. await pauses execution until the Promise resolves, making asynchronous code look synchronous. This is cleaner than .then() chains and easier to read and write.
days.interactive_task: Rewrite a fetch call using async/await instead of .then().

quiz.question: What keyword makes a function asynchronous?
What does await do?
Can you use await outside an async function?
How do you handle errors with async/await?
What does an async function always return?

days.title: Array Destructuring
days.content: Destructuring allows you to extract values from arrays or properties from objects into distinct variables. For arrays, use square brackets on the left side: const [first, second] = [1, 2]. You can skip elements, use rest pattern (...), and provide default values. This makes code cleaner and more readable.
days.interactive_task: Use array destructuring to extract the first two values from an array.

quiz.question: What syntax is used for array destructuring?
How do you skip the second element?
What does the rest operator (...) do?
How do you provide a default value?
What will [a, b] = [1, 2, 3] assign to a and b?

days.title: Object Destructuring
days.content: Object destructuring extracts properties from objects into variables. Use curly braces on the left side: const {name, age} = person. You can rename variables, provide default values, and use nested destructuring. This is very useful when working with function parameters and API responses.
days.interactive_task: Destructure an object to extract specific properties, renaming one of them.

quiz.question: What syntax is used for object destructuring?
How do you rename a property during destructuring?
How do you provide a default value?
Can you destructure nested objects?
What is a common use for object destructuring?

days.title: Template Literals
days.content: Template literals (backticks ``) allow embedded expressions and multi-line strings. Use ${expression} to insert values directly into strings. This is much cleaner than string concatenation with +. Template literals also preserve whitespace and line breaks, making them ideal for HTML templates and long strings.

How do you insert a variable into a template literal?

Can you use expressions inside ${}?

days.title: Arrow Functions Deep Dive
days.content: Arrow functions (=>) have concise syntax and don't have their own this, arguments, super, or new.target. They're best for non-method functions and callbacks. The syntax varies: single parameter doesn't need parentheses, single expression doesn't need braces or return, but multiple parameters or statements do.

Arrow functions inherit this from surrounding scope
quiz.answer: Arrow functions inherit this from surrounding scope

When can you omit curly braces and return?

Where are arrow functions most commonly used?

days.content: Let's build a simple task manager web app. We'll use DOM manipulation to create, display, and delete tasks; localStorage to persist data; events for user interactions; and modern JavaScript features like arrow functions and template literals. This project will combine all the concepts we've learned.

courses.title: Java for Beginners
courses.description: A 25-day beginner-friendly Java course that teaches object-oriented programming fundamentals through hands-on practice.

days.title: Introduction to Java
days.content: Java is a powerful, object-oriented programming language known for its 'write once, run anywhere' capability. Java code is compiled to bytecode that runs on the Java Virtual Machine (JVM). Every Java program must have a class with a main method: public static void main(String[] args). Java is strongly typed and uses semicolons to end statements.
days.interactive_task: Write a Java program that prints 'Hello World' to the console.

quiz.question: Who created Java?
What is the entry point of a Java program?
What does JVM stand for?
Which keyword defines a class in Java?
What is the correct signature for the main method?

days.title: Variables and Data Types
days.content: Java is statically typed, meaning you must declare variable types. Primitive data types include: int (whole numbers), double (decimal numbers), boolean (true/false), char (single characters). Reference types include String (text). Variables are declared with type name = value;. For example: int age = 25; String name = 'Alice';
days.interactive_task: Declare variables for your name (String), age (int), and whether you're a student (boolean), then print them.

quiz.question: Which data type would you use for whole numbers?
How do you declare a variable in Java?
Which is a valid variable name?
What is the default value of a boolean?
Which data type stores text?

days.title: Operators
days.content: Java has arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /, %), comparison operators (==, !=, >, <, >=, <=), and logical operators (&&, ||, !). The + operator can also concatenate strings. Java follows operator precedence rules - multiplication and division happen before addition and subtraction. Use parentheses to control order.
days.interactive_task: Create two number variables and use operators to calculate their sum, product, and check if the first is greater than the second.

quiz.question: What does the % operator do?
Which operator checks if two values are equal?
What is the result of 10 / 3 in Java?
Which logical operator means 'AND'?
What does 'Hello ' + 'World' produce?

days.title: Conditional Statements
days.content: Java uses if, else if, and else for conditional logic. The condition must be a boolean expression. Code blocks are defined with curly braces {}. You can also use the ternary operator: condition ? valueIfTrue : valueIfFalse. Switch statements are useful for multiple discrete values.
days.interactive_task: Write a program that checks if a number is positive, negative, or zero and prints the result.

quiz.question: What keyword starts a conditional statement?
What type must the condition be?
How do you write multiple conditions?
What is the syntax of the ternary operator?
options: if condition then value else value

quiz.question: When would you use a switch statement?

days.title: Loops
days.content: Java has for loops (specific number of iterations), while loops (while condition is true), and do-while loops (execute at least once). For loops have initialization, condition, and iteration parts. While loops check condition before execution, do-while check after. Use break to exit loops and continue to skip to next iteration.
days.interactive_task: Use a for loop to print numbers from 1 to 5.

quiz.question: What are the three parts of a for loop?
When does a while loop check its condition?
What does i++ mean?
How do you exit a loop early?
Which loop always executes at least once?

days.title: Arrays
days.content: Arrays store multiple values of the same type. Declare arrays with type[] name or type name[]. Create arrays with new type[size] or with initializer {value1, value2}. Access elements with [index] starting at 0. Arrays have a .length property. Java arrays are fixed-size once created.
days.interactive_task: Create an array of three favorite numbers and print the second number.

quiz.question: How do you declare an integer array?
What index is the first element in an array?
How do you create an array with values 1, 2, 3?
How do you get the length of an array?
Can you change the size of an array after creation?

days.title: Methods
days.content: Methods are functions defined inside classes. They have a return type (or void if no return), name, parameters, and a body. Methods can be called on objects or statically. Use the return keyword to return a value. Method parameters are passed by value in Java.
days.interactive_task: Create a method that takes two numbers and returns their sum.

quiz.question: What keyword is used if a method doesn't return anything?
How do you return a value from a method?
What are the parts of a method declaration?
How do you call a method named calculate?
Are Java parameters passed by reference or value?

days.title: Classes and Objects
days.content: Classes are blueprints for objects. Objects are instances of classes. Define a class with class ClassName { }. Classes contain fields (variables) and methods. Create objects with new ClassName(). Access object members with dot notation. Each object has its own copy of instance fields.
days.interactive_task: Create a simple Person class with name and age fields, then create an object of that class.

quiz.question: What keyword creates an object?
How do you access an object's field?
What is the relationship between class and object?
Where are classes defined?
Can one class have multiple objects?

days.title: Constructors
days.content: Constructors are special methods that initialize new objects. They have the same name as the class and no return type. If you don't define a constructor, Java provides a default no-argument constructor. You can overload constructors with different parameters. Use this() to call another constructor from the same class.
days.interactive_task: Add a constructor to your Person class that initializes name and age.

quiz.question: What is the name of a constructor?
What is the return type of a constructor?
When is the default constructor provided?
What is constructor overloading?
How do you call another constructor?

days.title: Access Modifiers
days.content: Access modifiers control visibility of classes, fields, and methods. public: accessible from anywhere, private: only within the same class, protected: within package and subclasses, and default (no modifier): within package only. Good practice: make fields private and provide public getter/setter methods.
days.interactive_task: Make the fields in your Person class private and add public getter methods.

quiz.question: Which modifier allows access from anywhere?
Which modifier is most restrictive?
What is the default access (no modifier)?
Why make fields private?
What are getter and setter methods?
options: Methods to get and set private fields
quiz.answer: Methods to get and set private fields

days.title: Inheritance
days.content: Inheritance allows a class to inherit fields and methods from another class. Use extends keyword: class Child extends Parent. The child class (subclass) inherits from the parent class (superclass). Java supports single inheritance (one parent only). Use super() to call parent constructor and super.method() to call parent methods.
days.interactive_task: Create a Student class that extends your Person class and adds a grade field.

quiz.question: What keyword is used for inheritance?
How many parents can a class have in Java?
What does super() call?
What is method overriding?
options: Changing a parent method in child
quiz.answer: Changing a parent method in child

quiz.question: Can private methods be inherited?

days.title: Polymorphism
days.content: Polymorphism means 'many forms'. In Java, a reference variable of a superclass can refer to objects of its subclasses. This allows writing flexible code that works with different types. Method overriding enables runtime polymorphism - the JVM decides which method to call based on the actual object type at runtime.
days.interactive_task: Create a method in Person that is overridden in Student, then call it polymorphically.

quiz.question: What does polymorphism mean?
Can a Parent reference hold a Child object?
When is the method to call determined in polymorphism?
What is required for polymorphism to work?
What is the difference between overriding and overloading?
options: Overriding: same method different classes, Overloading: same class different parameters
quiz.answer: Overriding: same method different classes, Overloading: same class different parameters

days.title: Abstract Classes and Methods
days.content: Abstract classes cannot be instantiated and may contain abstract methods (without implementation). Use abstract keyword for both abstract classes and methods. Subclasses must implement all abstract methods or be abstract themselves. Abstract classes are useful for defining common interfaces while leaving implementation details to subclasses.
days.interactive_task: Create an abstract Shape class with an abstract area() method, then create a concrete Circle class that extends it.

quiz.question: Can you create an object of an abstract class?
What keyword defines an abstract class?
What must subclasses do with abstract methods?
Can abstract classes have concrete methods?
When would you use an abstract class?
options: When you want to share code but require specific implementations
quiz.answer: When you want to share code but require specific implementations

days.title: Interfaces
days.content: Interfaces define contracts that classes must implement. All interface methods are implicitly public and abstract (before Java 8). Classes implement interfaces with implements keyword. A class can implement multiple interfaces. Interfaces can have constants (public static final fields) and default methods (Java 8+).
days.interactive_task: Create a Drawable interface with a draw() method, and make your Circle class implement it.

quiz.question: What keyword defines an interface?
What keyword implements an interface?
How many interfaces can a class implement?
What are interface methods by default?
Can interfaces have fields?

days.title: Exception Handling
days.content: Exceptions are events that disrupt normal program flow. Java uses try-catch-finally blocks for exception handling. Code that might throw exceptions goes in try block. Catch blocks handle specific exceptions. Finally block always executes. Checked exceptions must be handled or declared, unchecked exceptions (RuntimeException) don't.
days.interactive_task: Write code that tries to parse a string to integer and catches the NumberFormatException.

quiz.question: What keyword starts the exception-prone code block?
What keyword handles the exception?
What block always executes?
How do you throw an exception?
What is the difference between checked and unchecked exceptions?
options: Checked must be handled, unchecked don't
Unchecked must be handled, checked don't
Checked are for files, unchecked for math
quiz.answer: Checked must be handled, unchecked don't

days.title: Collections - ArrayList
days.content: ArrayList is a resizable array implementation of the List interface. It grows automatically as needed. ArrayLists can only hold objects, not primitives (use wrapper classes). Common methods: .add(), .get(), .remove(), .size(), .contains(). ArrayLists maintain insertion order and allow duplicates.
days.interactive_task: Create an ArrayList of strings, add some names, and print them using a loop.

quiz.question: How do you import ArrayList?
How do you create an ArrayList of Strings?
How do you add an element to ArrayList?
How do you get an element by index?
Can ArrayLists hold primitives directly?

days.title: Collections - HashMap
days.content: HashMap stores key-value pairs and allows fast retrieval by key. Keys must be unique, values can duplicate. HashMap doesn't maintain order. Common methods: .put(key, value), .get(key), .remove(key), .containsKey(key), .keySet(), .values(). Use wrapper classes for primitive keys/values.
days.interactive_task: Create a HashMap that maps student names to their grades, then look up a grade by name.

quiz.question: How do you create a HashMap?
How do you add a key-value pair?
What happens if you put with an existing key?
How do you get all keys?
Does HashMap maintain order?

days.title: File Handling - Reading Files
days.content: Java provides several ways to read files. Use BufferedReader with FileReader for text files, or Files.readAllLines() for simple cases. Always close resources with try-with-resources to avoid leaks. File operations can throw IOException, which must be handled.
days.interactive_task: Write a program that reads a text file and prints its contents.

quiz.question: What exception do file operations throw?
What is try-with-resources?
options: A way to automatically close resources
quiz.answer: A way to automatically close resources

quiz.question: How do you read all lines from a file easily?
What class is commonly used for reading text files?
Where is Files class located?

days.title: File Handling - Writing Files
days.content: To write files, use BufferedWriter with FileWriter, or Files.write() for simple cases. You can append to existing files or overwrite them. Use try-with-resources to ensure files are closed properly. Remember to handle IOException when working with files.
days.interactive_task: Write a program that writes your name and age to a text file.

quiz.question: How do you write to a file with BufferedWriter?
How do you append to a file instead of overwriting?
What does Files.write() do?
How do you create a new line in a file?
What happens if the file doesn't exist when writing?

days.title: String Methods
days.content: String is immutable in Java. Common methods: .length(), .charAt(index), .substring(start, end), .toUpperCase(), .toLowerCase(), .trim(), .equals(), .contains(), .startsWith(), .endsWith(). Use StringBuilder for efficient string manipulation when many changes are needed.
days.interactive_task: Take a string with extra spaces, trim it, convert to uppercase, and check if it contains 'JAVA'.

quiz.question: Are Java strings mutable?
How do you compare strings for equality?
What does 'hello'.substring(1, 4) return?
Which class is better for many string manipulations?
What does .trim() do?

days.title: Static Members
days.content: Static members belong to the class rather than instances. Static variables are shared by all instances. Static methods can be called without creating an object. Use static for utility methods and constants. Static blocks run when the class is loaded. You cannot access instance members from static context.
days.interactive_task: Add a static counter to your Person class that tracks how many Person objects have been created.

quiz.question: What keyword makes a member static?
How do you call a static method?
Are static variables shared?
Can static methods access instance variables?
What is a common use of static?

days.title: Packages and Import
days.content: Packages organize related classes and avoid naming conflicts. Declare a package at the top of a file: package com.example.mypackage;. Import classes from other packages with import package.Classname; or import package.*;. Java has many built-in packages like java.lang (automatically imported), java.util, java.io.
days.interactive_task: Create a class in a package and import it in another class.

quiz.question: Where is the package declaration placed?
How do you import all classes from a package?
Which package is automatically imported?
What is the purpose of packages?
How are packages related to directories?

days.title: Enums
days.content: Enums define a fixed set of constants. They are type-safe and can have fields, methods, and constructors. Enums are implicitly final and extend java.lang.Enum. Use enums instead of integer constants for better readability and type safety. Enums can be used in switch statements.
days.interactive_task: Create an enum for days of the week and use it in a switch statement.

quiz.question: What keyword defines an enum?
Are enums type-safe?
Can enums have methods?
What do enums extend?
When should you use enums?

days.title: Generics
days.content: Generics provide type safety at compile time. They allow you to write classes, interfaces, and methods that work with different types. Use angle brackets <T> to declare type parameters. Generics prevent ClassCastException and eliminate casting. Common uses: Collections like List<String>, Map<Integer, String>.
days.interactive_task: Create a generic Box class that can hold any type of object.

quiz.question: What symbols are used for generics?
What is the main benefit of generics?
Can primitives be used in generics?
What is type erasure?
options: Removing generic type information at runtime
quiz.answer: Removing generic type information at runtime

quiz.question: Where are generics commonly used?

days.title: Final Project - Student Management System
days.content: Let's build a simple student management system. We'll use classes for Student and Course, ArrayLists for storage, file I/O for persistence, and a simple menu system. This project will combine OOP principles, collections, file handling, and user input.
days.interactive_task: Build a student management system that can add students, list all students, save to file, and load from file.

How would you make the Student class properly encapsulated?

What principle allows adding new student types easily?

courses.title: SQL for Beginners
courses.description: A 25-day beginner-friendly SQL course that teaches database fundamentals through hands-on practice.

days.title: Introduction to Databases and SQL
days.content: SQL (Structured Query Language) is used to manage and query relational databases. A database stores data in tables with rows and columns. Each table has a name and columns with specific data types. SQL has different types of commands: DDL (Data Definition Language) for structure, DML (Data Manipulation Language) for data, and DQL (Data Query Language) for querying.
days.interactive_task: Write a SQL comment explaining what you want to learn about databases.

quiz.question: What does SQL stand for?
How is data organized in a relational database?
options: In tables with rows and columns
quiz.answer: In tables with rows and columns

quiz.question: Which SQL command type is used for querying data?
What is a row in a database table called?
What is a column in a database table called?

days.title: Creating Databases and Tables
days.content: Use CREATE DATABASE to create a new database and CREATE TABLE to create tables. When creating tables, specify column names and data types like INT (integer), VARCHAR (variable-length string), DATE, etc. The PRIMARY KEY uniquely identifies each record. Use USE database_name to select a database.
days.interactive_task: Create a database called 'school' and a 'students' table with id, name, and age columns.

quiz.question: Which command creates a new database?
What data type would you use for a person's name?
What is a primary key?
options: A unique identifier for each record
quiz.answer: A unique identifier for each record

quiz.question: How do you select a database to use?
Which keyword makes a column auto-increment?

days.title: INSERT Statement
days.content: The INSERT statement adds new records to a table. Specify the table name, column names (optional if inserting all columns), and values. String values must be enclosed in single quotes. Use INSERT INTO table_name (column1, column2) VALUES (value1, value2); to insert specific columns, or omit column names to insert all columns in order.
days.interactive_task: Insert three student records into your students table.

quiz.question: Which statement adds data to a table?
How are string values enclosed in SQL?
What happens if you omit column names in INSERT?
options: You must provide values for all columns
quiz.answer: You must provide values for all columns

quiz.question: Can you insert multiple rows with one INSERT statement?
What is the correct syntax for INSERT?

days.title: SELECT Statement
days.content: SELECT retrieves data from tables. Use SELECT * to get all columns or specify column names. FROM specifies the table. You can use WHERE to filter results. The basic syntax is: SELECT column1, column2 FROM table_name;. Use ORDER BY to sort results and LIMIT to restrict the number of rows returned.
days.interactive_task: Write a SELECT statement to get all students from your students table.

quiz.question: Which statement retrieves data from a table?
What does SELECT * mean?
Which clause specifies the table to query?
How do you sort results by a column?
How do you limit the number of rows returned?

days.title: WHERE Clause
days.content: The WHERE clause filters records based on conditions. Use comparison operators: =, != or <>, >, <, >=, <=. For multiple conditions, use AND, OR, and parentheses for grouping. Use LIKE for pattern matching with % (any characters) and _ (single character). IS NULL checks for null values.
days.interactive_task: Select students who are older than 20 from your students table.

quiz.question: Which clause filters records in SQL?
Which operator checks for equality?
What does % represent in LIKE patterns?
How do you check for null values?
Which logical operator requires all conditions to be true?

days.title: UPDATE Statement
days.content: UPDATE modifies existing records in a table. Use SET to specify new values and WHERE to identify which records to update. Always use WHERE with UPDATE unless you want to update all records. The syntax is: UPDATE table_name SET column1 = value1, column2 = value2 WHERE condition;
days.interactive_task: Update the age of a specific student in your students table.

quiz.question: Which statement modifies existing records?
Which clause specifies which records to update?
What happens if you omit WHERE in UPDATE?
How do you update multiple columns?
Can you update a primary key?

days.title: DELETE Statement
days.content: DELETE removes records from a table. Use WHERE to specify which records to delete. Without WHERE, all records are deleted (but the table structure remains). The syntax is: DELETE FROM table_name WHERE condition;. Use TRUNCATE TABLE to delete all records faster, but it cannot be rolled back.
days.interactive_task: Delete a specific student from your students table.

quiz.question: Which statement removes records from a table?
What happens if you omit WHERE in DELETE?
What is the difference between DELETE and TRUNCATE?
options: TRUNCATE is faster but can't be rolled back
quiz.answer: TRUNCATE is faster but can't be rolled back

quiz.question: How do you delete all records from a table?
Can you delete a record that doesn't exist?

days.title: Data Types
days.content: SQL data types define what kind of data a column can hold. Common types: INT (integer), DECIMAL/NUMERIC (exact numbers), VARCHAR (variable-length strings), CHAR (fixed-length strings), DATE (date without time), DATETIME/TIMESTAMP (date and time), BOOLEAN (true/false). Choose appropriate types for your data to save space and ensure validity.
days.interactive_task: Create a table with different data types: integer, string, decimal, and date.

quiz.question: Which data type would you use for a price?
What is the difference between CHAR and VARCHAR?
options: CHAR is fixed length, VARCHAR is variable
VARCHAR is fixed length, CHAR is variable
CHAR is for numbers, VARCHAR for text
quiz.answer: CHAR is fixed length, VARCHAR is variable

quiz.question: Which type stores true/false values?
What does INT(11) mean?
Which type would you use for a birth date?

days.title: Constraints
days.content: Constraints enforce rules on data. Common constraints: PRIMARY KEY (unique identifier), FOREIGN KEY (references another table), NOT NULL (value required), UNIQUE (all values different), CHECK (custom condition), DEFAULT (default value). Constraints ensure data integrity and relationships between tables.
days.interactive_task: Add NOT NULL constraint to the name column and a CHECK constraint to ensure age is positive.

quiz.question: Which constraint ensures a column cannot have NULL?
What does a PRIMARY KEY constraint do?
options: Makes values unique and not null
quiz.answer: Makes values unique and not null

quiz.question: Which constraint links to another table?
How do you set a default value?
Can a table have multiple UNIQUE constraints?

days.title: ORDER BY
days.content: ORDER BY sorts the result set by one or more columns. Use ASC for ascending order (default) or DESC for descending order. You can sort by multiple columns by separating them with commas. The syntax is: SELECT columns FROM table ORDER BY column1 ASC, column2 DESC;

days.title: Aggregate Functions
days.content: Aggregate functions perform calculations on multiple rows and return a single value. Common functions: COUNT() counts rows, SUM() adds values, AVG() calculates average, MAX() finds maximum, MIN() finds minimum. Use GROUP BY with aggregates to calculate values for groups of rows.

days.title: GROUP BY
days.content: GROUP BY groups rows that have the same values in specified columns. It's used with aggregate functions to calculate values for each group. The HAVING clause filters groups (similar to WHERE for rows). GROUP BY comes after WHERE and before ORDER BY.

days.title: JOIN Basics
days.content: JOIN combines rows from two or more tables based on related columns. INNER JOIN returns only matching rows from both tables. LEFT JOIN returns all rows from the left table and matching rows from the right table. RIGHT JOIN is the opposite of LEFT JOIN. FULL JOIN returns all rows when there's a match in either table.

days.title: ALTER TABLE
days.content: ALTER TABLE modifies an existing table structure. You can: ADD a new column, DROP a column, MODIFY/ALTER a column's data type, ADD/DROP constraints, RENAME a column or table. The syntax varies by database system. Always backup data before altering table structure.

days.title: Indexes
days.content: Indexes improve query performance by creating a quick lookup structure. They're like book indexes - they help find data faster without scanning the entire table. CREATE INDEX creates an index, DROP INDEX removes it. Primary keys are automatically indexed. Don't over-index as indexes slow down INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE.

days.title: Subqueries
days.content: Subqueries (nested queries) are queries within queries. They can be used in SELECT, FROM, WHERE, and HAVING clauses. Subqueries must be enclosed in parentheses. They can return a single value, multiple values, or a table. Use EXISTS to check if a subquery returns any rows.

days.title: Views
days.content: Views are virtual tables based on the result of a SQL query. They don't store data themselves but display data from underlying tables. CREATE VIEW creates a view, DROP VIEW removes it. Views can simplify complex queries, enhance security by hiding columns, and provide logical data organization.

days.title: String Functions
days.content: SQL provides functions for string manipulation. Common functions: CONCAT() joins strings, LENGTH() returns string length, UPPER()/LOWER() change case, TRIM() removes spaces, SUBSTRING() extracts part of string, REPLACE() replaces text. These functions help clean and transform string data.

days.title: Date Functions
days.content: Date functions manipulate and extract information from dates. Common functions: NOW()/CURDATE() get current date/time, DATE_FORMAT() formats dates, DATEDIFF() calculates difference between dates, DATE_ADD()/DATE_SUB() add/subtract time intervals, EXTRACT() gets specific parts (year, month, day).

days.title: NULL Functions
days.content: NULL represents missing or unknown data. Use IS NULL and IS NOT NULL to check for NULL. Functions for handling NULL: COALESCE() returns first non-NULL value, IFNULL()/ISNULL() return specified value if NULL, NULLIF() returns NULL if values are equal. Be careful with NULL in comparisons and calculations.

days.title: Transactions
days.content: Transactions group multiple SQL operations into a single unit of work. They follow ACID properties: Atomicity (all or nothing), Consistency (valid state), Isolation (concurrent operations don't interfere), Durability (changes persist). Use BEGIN TRANSACTION, COMMIT to save changes, ROLLBACK to undo changes.

days.title: Stored Procedures
days.content: Stored procedures are prepared SQL code that can be saved and reused. They can accept parameters and return results. CREATE PROCEDURE creates a procedure, CALL executes it. Procedures improve performance (precompiled), enhance security, and reduce network traffic. They can contain complex logic with variables and control flow.

days.title: Normalization
days.content: Normalization organizes data to reduce redundancy and improve integrity. First Normal Form (1NF): atomic values, no repeating groups. Second Normal Form (2NF): 1NF + no partial dependencies (all non-key attributes depend on whole primary key). Third Normal Form (3NF): 2NF + no transitive dependencies (non-key attributes depend only on primary key).

days.title: Backup and Restore
days.content: Regular backups protect against data loss. Use mysqldump for MySQL, pg_dump for PostgreSQL, or database-specific tools. Backups can be full (all data), differential (changes since last full), or incremental (changes since last backup). Test restores regularly. Consider backup frequency based on data importance and change rate.
